message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute pericarditis, which is commonly associated with autoimmune diseases. Among the options, only Anti-histone antibodies are associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus, which can cause pericarditis as a symptom. Anti-cardiolipin antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, while Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are associated with primary biliary cirrhosis and Anti-cyclic citrullinated antibodies are associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest pericarditis, which can sometimes be associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Anti-histone antibodies are found in drug-induced lupus and are a marker for SLE. Anti-cardiolipin antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, which may be present in SLE but is not directly related to pericarditis. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are associated with primary biliary cholangitis and anti-cyclic citrullinated antibodies are associated with rheumatoid arthritis, which are not related to pericarditis or SLE.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of pericarditis and swollen joints, which suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Anti-histone antibodies are commonly found in drug-induced lupus and can also be seen in SLE. Anti-cardiolipin antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are associated with primary biliary cirrhosis. Anti-cyclic citrullinated antibodies are associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Among the options, only Anti-histone antibodies are associated with drug-induced lupus and acute pericarditis. The patient’s history of hydralazine use is a risk factor for drug-induced lupus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and ECG findings suggest pericarditis, and the swollen and tender joints suggest rheumatoid arthritis. Anti-histone antibodies are found in drug-induced lupus, which can be caused by hydralazine, the patient’s medication. The other options are not typically associated with these conditions.

Anti-histone antibodies are commonly found in patients with drug-induced lupus, which can occur as a side effect of hydralazine. The other options are not commonly associated with SLE.

The patient presents with symptoms consistent with acute pericarditis, which is often associated with connective tissue diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Anti-histone antibodies are commonly found in SLE and drug-induced lupus. Anti-cardiolipin antibodies are associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, which can cause thrombosis and miscarriages. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are found in primary biliary cholangitis. Anti-cyclic citrullinated antibodies are found in rheumatoid arthritis.

Among the options, only anti-histone antibodies are commonly present in SLE. Anti-cardiolipin antibodies are seen in antiphospholipid syndrome, anti-mitochondrial antibodies are seen in primary biliary cholangitis, and anti-cyclic citrullinated antibodies are seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with acute pericarditis, which is associated with anti-histone antibodies. The other options are associated with different diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (anti-cardiolipin antibodies), primary biliary cirrhosis (anti-mitochondrial antibodies), and rheumatoid arthritis (anti-cyclic citrullinated antibodies). The fact that the patient’s antinuclear antibody is negative also makes these options less likely.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute pericarditis, which often presents with chest pain that improves when sitting up and leaning forward. The swollen hands and wrists suggest a possible autoimmune condition, and the negative ANA makes options B, C, and D less likely. Anti-histone antibodies are commonly present in drug-induced lupus, which can be caused by hydralazine, a medication the patient is currently taking.
